content.text: Complete the following sentence
The car has the largest acceleration in section
Calculate the distance travelled by the car between time \(= 20s\) and time \(= 35s\)
distance travelled = .........m
section LM
section MN
Describe the motion of the car during:
Another car travels a distance of \(500 \text{m}\) in a time of \(20 \text{s}\)
Calculate the average speed of this car
average speed = .........m/s
[Total: 9]
Fig. 1.1 shows the speedâ€“time graph for a car travelling along a flat, straight road. The graph has four sections, labelled JK, KL, LM and MN
State the time taken for one complete oscillation. Use the information in Fig. 2.1
Another student uses a different pendulum and measures the time for 15 complete oscillations. The time for 15 complete oscillations is 11.7 s
Calculate the average time for one complete oscillation
Fig. 2.2 represents a pendulum. P and Q are the extreme positions of the pendulum bob. R is the position of the bob when the string is vertical
A student uses a stop-watch to measure the time for one complete oscillation of a pendulum
Fig. 2.1 shows his measurement
The mass of the wooden beam is \(40 \text{kg}\)
Calculate the weight of the wooden beam
weight of beam = .........N
Two children balance the wooden beam horizontally on a log. The wooden beam pivots on the log to make the see-saw
Fig. 3.1 shows the children on the see-saw
The see-saw balances horizontally, as shown in Fig. 3.1. The weight of child B is 360N
Calculate the weight \(W\) of child A
State and use the principle of moments in your answer
weight $W$ of child A = .........N
[Total: 6]
A wooden beam is used in a see-saw
The weight of the load is \(15N.\) The load is raised a vertical distance of \(0.80m.\)
Calculate the work done on the load
work done on load = .........J
Describe **one** way in which energy is wasted as the electric motor lifts the load
A hydroelectric power station generates electrical power using the energy stored in water behind a dam
Describe how a hydroelectric power station generates electrical power
An electric motor lifts a load
Fig. 4.1 shows the arrangement
A student uses the apparatus in Fig. 5.1 to compare how different surfaces absorb infrared radiation
There are two metal containers. One has a dull black surface and the other has a shiny white surface
Before heating, the air inside the metal containers is at the same temperature
The Bunsen burner flame is the same distance from each metal container. The Bunsen burner flame emits infrared radiation and heats the metal containers for three minutes
Explain the difference between the temperatures of the air inside the two metal containers after heating for three minutes

A teacher has some equipment for comparing thermal conductivity. The teacher has four metal rods and one glass rod. The metals are brass, copper, iron and steel. All five rods are the same size and shape
Describe how the teacher may use the rods to compare the thermal conductivity of the five materials
You may draw a labelled diagram as part of your answer
State the name of the dashed line labelled line Y in Fig. 6.1
On Fig. 6.1, label the angle of incidence for the ray of red light at point P. Use the letter X
The ray of red light travels from the glass into the air at point P
On Fig. 6.1, draw the path for the ray of red light after it leaves the glass at point P.
Fig. 6.1 represents a ray of red light travelling into and through a glass block
Use the information on Fig. 6.2 to determine the focal length of the lens
focal length of lens = .........cm
State two characteristics of the image in Fig. 6.2
Fig. 6.2 represents a converging lens that is forming the image of an object
the amplitude of the wave
amplitude of wave = .........cm
the frequency of the wave
frequency of wave = .........Hz
A transverse wave passes through a medium. Fig. 7.1 shows the displacement of particles in the medium
Using the information in Fig. 7.1, determine:
Complete the chart in Fig. 7.2 by adding the names of the missing regions.
The speed of yellow light is \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\). The wavelength of yellow light is \(5.8 \times 10^{-7} \text{m}\)
Calculate the frequency of yellow light
frequency = .........Hz
Fig. 7.2 shows the regions of the electromagnetic spectrum in order of increasing frequency. Two of the regions are **not** labelled
Calculate the combined resistance of the two resistors shown in Fig. 8.1
combined resistance = .........$\Omega$
The potential difference across the \(8.0\Omega\) resistor is \(2.0\mathrm{V}\)
Calculate the current in the resistor
current = .........A
State the name of the particles that move through the metal wires when there is a current in the circuit
A student measures the potential difference across the \(16\Omega\) resistor by using a meter
On Fig. 8.1, draw the electrical symbol for this meter and its connections.
[Total: 8]
Fig. 8.1 shows the circuit diagram for a \(16\Omega\) resistor and an \(8.0\Omega\) resistor connected to a \(6.0\mathrm{V}\) battery
The power input to the router circuit is 9.0W. The potential difference across the router circuit is 12V
Calculate the current in the router circuit
current in router circuit = .........A
The energy used by the router each hour is \(0.0090\mathrm{kWh}\) . One unit (kWh) of energy costs 50 cents
Calculate the cost of using the router for 24 hours
cost for 24 hours = .........cents

The router uses a transformer. The number of turns \(N_{\mathrm{p}}\) on the primary coil of the transformer is 3600. The primary voltage \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\) to the transformer is 240V. The secondary voltage \(V_{\mathrm{s}}\) of the transformer is 12V
Calculate the number of turns \(N_{\mathrm{s}}\) on the secondary coil of the transformer
number of turns on secondary coil = .........
The mains plug for the router includes a fuse that protects the router
Explain how a fuse works
Fig. 9.1 shows a router. The router emits Wi-Fi signals
Determine which two nuclides have the same number of nucleons
Determine which nuclide has the largest number of neutrons
Table 10.1 describes four nuclides
Plutonium-241 has a half-life of 14 years
A sample of radioactive material contains 72 mg of plutonium-241
Calculate the mass of plutonium-241 remaining in the sample after 42 years
mass of plutonium-241 remaining = .........mg
[Total: 6]
State the name of the force that keeps the planets in orbit around the Sun
State the name of the galaxy that includes the Solar System
The Solar System includes the Sun and eight planets
State the meaning of the term light-year
Describe the evidence for an expanding Universe
